title: Former senior police officers risk arrest as they join Extinction Rebellion protest
text:
Rob Cooper, former Police Chief Superintendent and now a supporter of Extinction Rebellion

Former senior police officers will risk arrest as they join the climate protest on Monday despite pleas from their colleagues over the waste of resources.

Just days after the Metropolitan Police warned that the protests were taking officers away from other vital roles and placing a greater burden on the force than terrorism, several retired officers have released a video explaining why they have joined Extinction Rebellion.

The most senior is Rob Cooper, 60, a former Chief Superintendent of Devon and Cornwall police.

He is risking arrest when he attends the protest in London on Monday, when the group has vowed to shut down Westminster.

"A lack of action now is going to cost us far more in the future"



Former police officers talk about why they were willing be arrested for #ExtinctionRebellion



Climate & #ecologicalbreakdown will impact everyone

We need #everybodynow to rebel for changehttps://t.co/MMx5Z6uhFNpic.twitter.com/U0WfOa1QRz









— Extinction Rebellion UK ��️ (@XRebellionUK) October 5, 2019

Mr Cooper, who retired a decade ago, said: “We really do face a climate emergency.

“There are times when I really struggle. I have three children and I have a grandchild”

Mr Cooper says that the pressure that climate change will have on the emergency services is one of the reasons that he has joined Extinction Rebellion, but admitted that at protests in April: “I did feel self-conscious because I was used to being on other side of the protest line.”

John Curran, a 49-year-old retired detective sergeant, was arrested at during the action earlier this year when he refused to leave Waterloo Bridge.

An image of John Curran in the video released by the group More

He claims that once the tapes were turned off the serving officers offered him words of support. He will return to the capital and risk arrest a second time today.

In a video released by Extinction Rebellion he said: “Had you told me five years ago ‘John, you will be arrested, you will be interview in a police cell’, I would have laughed at you.”

The pair will also be joined by Richard Ecclestone, a former Inspector who was taught by Cressida Dick at the college of policing. He argued: “A lack of action now is going to cost us a far more in the future.”

Richard Ecclestone used to run Devon and Cornwall police's emergency response team More

The former soldier, whose role in Devon and Cornwall police was planning for emergencies, said: “The security services, both police and the military as well, would be engaged in trying to stop people from basically killing each other for resources. Basic resources like food and water.”
description: Former senior police officers will risk arrest as they join the climate protest on Monday despite pleas from their colleagues over the waste of resources.
